channel.title: Tank and spank
channel.description: Staring at crotches since Vanilla WoW

item.title: positioning image - just a step up from Paint!
item.dc:creator: clearly

item.title: Welcome to Tank and Spank!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
And welcome to the inaugural post! The idea behind Tank and spank has been bubbling round in the back of my head for quite some time now. You see I have been playing WoW for well over 5 years now (I know , I know GONL!!), and I have been tanking and staring at crotches for almost all of that time. I have had many highs, a few lows, a few burnt out moments, but overall I have always had a lot of fun. Back in May 2010, I decided that I needed a break from the game. We were moving back to the UK, we had a new born, Cataclysm was around the corner, ICC held little in the way of interest. So I let me account elapse, and said good bye to :
  • Wildecard (aka WC)
  • Safetyoff
  • Bubbleuc
  • Artaios
  • Turpin
And a bunch of other characters at various levels. I have been keeping up on alpha and beta news and with all the changes coming our way it truly looks like a new game is on the horizon. So I started planning this little site and by planning really I mean thinking about an idea. I wanted to write a little about the game I love, I wanted to write about tanking. I wanted to keep track of the changes to Tanking and share my thoughts. However I also wanted to explore making movies and using some of the social networking tools out there to find like minded individuals and to engage with. Enough rambling for now, without further ado I bid you farewell until the next post.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This is an example of a WordPress page, you could edit this to put information about yourself or your site so readers know where you are coming from. You can create as many pages like this one or sub-pages as you like and manage all of your content inside of WordPress.

item.title: Another tankadin video
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A few bad pulls, a few good ones. BubbleUc in action.

Nexus - 5 man run from Greg Stewart on Vimeo.

The movie was recorded on my Mac on the 2010-06-21 and features Bubbleuc - my tankadin.

item.title: Meet the protagonists
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I guess I could have continued on with my characters on Aman'Thul and continued raiding with truly great (if somewhat rowdy) bunch of guys. There was also a European Guild (The European Treaty - howdy folks) on AT that would have provided good raid times and several raid teams, but I wanted a fresh start, and having never played Horde that is the faction I wanted to play on. Oh and 30 ms latency... Hello! Certainly beats the ~200ms we used to have. So after a quick chat with my wife the decision was made - time to reroll! With all the changes on it's way a part of me wanted to wait for Cataclysm to hit and view the world anew, then again, I had never levelled horde so I also wanted to experience that, before the big re-design. I also wanted to remind myself (how painful) levelling a warrior is... Meet Clearly! Clearly (lvl 14) Tauren warrior. I had considered an Orc first and then save the Tauren for the Paladin class or Druid class later on, but I am sorry, they just look so bad ass and that deep booming voice and those horns... just won me over. I am levelling him as Fury for now, but will probably switch to protection around level 40 - talents permitting Clearly has been busy running around creating a guild the last few days, so he hasn't been concentrating on levelling, but finally he got his ten signatures together and I am pleased to announce the formation of <Keep calm and carry on> on Stormrage - EU. If you are keen on joining, being part of the journey, and you stumble across this, just leave me an in game mail or post here with your toon name and I'll hook you up with an invite. My other characters planned or otherwise are:
  • Safetyoff (troll / hunter) at time of writing he's comfortably sitting at lvl 23. You might wander why I am including a hunter, well I am a big fan of the hunter class. Nothing beats this class in terms of skill, solo - play and versatility. That's right time for some Hunter tanking talk - well Ok pet tanking...
  • Safely (Belf / Paladin) subject to change
  • Treadsafely (tauren/troll / Druid)
  • (Orc/Undead DK)
Enough for now - more to come :)

item.title: Gundrak 5 man run - test video
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Just a quick test to see how the embedding of videos would work using Vimeo.

Gun'Drak - 5 man run from Greg Stewart on Vimeo.

The movie was recorded on my Mac on the 2010-06-16 and features Bubbleuc - my tankadin.

item.title: At level 15
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded: A whole new game starts - the dungeon finder is made available and the tanking journey starts. So I hit 15 last night and straight away queued for a dungeon. It was quite a surprise to be tanking again, for one I was missing the complete arsenal of abilities a lvl 80 warrior has at his disposal: Shield Slam,Shockwave, Sword and Board, Devastate andWarbringer (in no particular order) and the lack of rage was quite a schock. I found myself limited to just basically applying stacks of sunders and if it was a larger group of mobs, pray that I had enough time on them to build enough rage for a Thunder Clap. None of it is really a concern, since instancing is easy and most people know how to get out of trouble, but it's funny as a tank I always feel responsible if a mob runs off, even if the DPS was targeting the wrong target or started hitting it before you even got near. At this level taunt is your friend! Sunder Armor a close second and then rage permitting, well take your pick of TC or Revenge or Heroic Strike. Oh and do yourself a favour, grab a shield and go into defensive stance! Your healer will thank you. :)

item.title: Spending your first talent points
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded:
In yesterday's post I commented on my lack of rage generation in some five mans. Combine that with a comment that someone made in another run about my spec being wrong (and while my current spec is not ideal, he was referring about me tanking as Fury - everybody is an expert these days). I thought I'd jot down a few notes on the topic. As you hit level 10, you get to spend your first talent points, that is you get to make a choice about the direction you want to take your character in. To be honest though, even if you are committed to tanking your way to 80, for you now you could safely ignore most of the tanking talents and purely focus on the DPS ones. After all, the faster things die the quicker you'll get there. I should point out that, and most of you probably know this already,things will change drastically in Cataclysm and you will be locked into the tree you spend your first point in (until you reach the bottom of the tree that is, then you can put some points in the other trees), for now though we still in a world where you can pick and mix. So what spec should you focus on for the first ten levels? As always there's no one way, but personally I think that your first five points should go into Cruelty, followed by 5 points in Unbridled Wrath, so your tree would you look like this: Wowhead 10-20 talent spec I know, Iknow, if you were to armory Clearly right now you'd see I have 2 points in Armored to the Teeth, I wasn't paying attention and just went for the fury components of a level 80 warrior. At level 80 when you have pretty big armor stats this is a great talent, however at level 19 with my current gear this results in 25.90 extra AP (the formula looks like this: (armor value/108)*2, i.e. (1399/108)*2), not exactly much to write home about. In contrast for Wildecard, who has 28115 armor that translates to ~ 780 AP (since WC is maxed out the formula looks like this (armor value/108)*3)]. For now best to max outUnbridled Wrath - and that also fixes any rages issues you might be experiencing, or at least addresses them. :) For some further reading on warrior levelling have a look at these two links (slightly out fo date, but still informative):
  • Warrior Leveling Demystified
  • Of Steel Guidelines for New & Leveling Warriors

item.title: Shield Block, Defensive Stance and you
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded: So while talking about low level tanking, I spoke a little about Rage generation and some of the abilities we have at our disposal. I forgot to mention how you actually get Defensive Stance , to be fair I had completely forgotten: it's through a quest you can pick up at level 10 (Horde | Alliance | Draenei). What does Defensive Stance give you? Well apart from certain specific tanking abilities, ie.Sunder Armor and Taunt,it also affects some of your attributes. You take 10% less damage and your damage generates 5% more threat (at some stage we'll talk a little more about threat, but in a nutshell this is what makes mobs stick to you). Once you hit level 16, you get access to one of the staples of tanking : Shield Block - it is considered so important because a blocked attack cannot not be a crit, so spam that button whenever it's off Cooldown (CD) - once again be aware that things are changing in Cataclysm, but for now we'll concentrate on what we know for sure. You can read up some more info on Block.

item.title: Some resources
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded: Other resources: http://www.wowwiki.com/Warriors_as_tanks http://tauntmaster.com/warrior.htm http://www.tankhard.com/ http://www.thesteelwarrior.org/forum/showthread.php?t=12173 http://www.mmo-champion.com/content/1676 - cataclysm changes and blue posts

item.title: A few words about positioning
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded: When you run in or charge, make sure no mob is hitting you from behind, or else be prepared for stuns and crits. Once you have a little bit of threat on the mobs, start positioning the mobs so that they have their backs to your group (remember melee, but in particular Rogues, like doing it from behind!) and you are facing your group (if anyone pulls aggro, you have clear line of sight of the mob running off to take a bite out of their intended target). I also like to stand with my back to a wall, if at all possible - good habit to get into for all those encounters where the boss/creature has an annoying knock back skill. [caption id="attachment_68" align="aligncenter" width="279" caption="Positioning and you!"][/caption] A picture speaks a thousand words right? ;) Be aware that a lot of folks will start unloading on the mobs as soon you as have charged in (regardless of level or difficulty). You might not have actually hit any of the targets yet, but that all too often doesn't concern some of your group members. Take a deep breath and be prepared to taunt the mob back (and take pleasure in the fact that your random dungeon queue last seconds and theirs starts at 15 minutes ;)). In a future post I'll share a macro to help with targets, well at least for group members that have an iota of common sense.

item.title: Macros
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded:
From: http://www.mmo-champion.com/threads/676764-Common-Warrior-Macros
#showtooltip Mark Target with skull /run if GetRaidTargetIndex("target")~=8 then SetRaidTarget("target",8)end "this macro will immediatly mark your target as skull, without having to right-click the portrait. this is awsome for heroics, it speeds things up and your dps (atleast the ones that arent braindead) will attack skull instead of randomly attacking something that you arent keeping much aggro on other then aoe."
#showtooltip Charge /cast bloodrage /cast [stance:2] Battle stance /stopcasting /cast Charge /cast [stance:1] Defensive Stance
This macro casts bloodrage, switches you into battle from def and allows you to charge. Click again to switch back to def

item.title: Levelling glyphs
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded:
At level 15, you get access to your first set of glyphs, one major () and one minor (). To help oiptimise your levelling experience and speed (just as food buffs, potions and enchants help) you should look at filling the newly opened up Glyph slots. [caption id="attachment_85" align="aligncenter" width="393" caption="Glyph interface"][/caption] The information below has been taken from: http://forums.worldofwarcraft.com/thread.html?topicId=17616372095&sid=1 "Glyph of Overpower This is an exceptional leveling ability. Getting parried kills your rage generation and is extremely annoying when facing defensive heavy mobs. This will also allow you to kill higher level mobs without too much trouble. Only higher than Sweeping Strikes because this is useful as soon as you get Overpower" I wasn't convinced about this, mainly because of the prohibitive costs of the glyph on our server (I guess that should have been an indication), which was ~25 gold. As soon as I saw one for under 10 gold, I grabbed it and having used it for 2-3 levels, I am won over! "Glyph of Battle A 50% increase to your Battle Shout timer. Definitely worth it if you can find it for a decent price on the AH. Less time wasted by using a GCD on putting up a new shout." No brainer here, especially if you are like me, and forget regularly to refresh it. You could argue that extending it by 4 minutes is worse, but it works for me while killing things. Others prefer going for : "Glyph of Bloodrage Personal favorite, simply because getting 20 free rage without taking damage every minute is great. Slightly better than Battle because with that 20 free rage I can throw up a new shout every minute for free of charge and begin a fight with 10 rage. All around a useful glyph and definitely has helped me a lot leveling. " Quite possibly I should have opted for the above glyph over the Battle one. Once you hit level 30 your next major glyph opens up. Based on the reading I have done, go for: "Glyph of Sweeping Strikes Another integral part of Arms leveling. You will kill two mobs at the same time, for free, taking hardly any extra damage. This makes leveling so much faster and efficient. Combined with a MS crit and an Overpower crit you can easily two-three shot mobs equal to your level at this stage, extremely useful! " Then you are going to have to wait til level 50 for the next glyph and it's only a minor one. Depending on what you choose @ 15 go for either Glyph of Battle or Glyph of Bloodrage. I will be switching over to protection around level 6,0 so I won't be focusing anymore on DPS based glyphs but for completeness sake, the next glyphs are available:
  • @ 70 - 3 minor
  • @ 80 - 3 major

item.title: tier 11 video is here
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded: Courtesy of MMO- Champion:

item.title: LoTRO : the warden
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded:
I haven't been playing much WoW recently, since the LoTRO has gone free to play I decided to go and take a peak and rolled a Warden on Gladden. In LoTRO there are two types of tanks:
  • Guardian, traditional tank
  • Warden, AoE (Area Of Effect) threat tank relying on gambits
Gambits are basically finishers for combos, i.e. execute a sequence of attacks in order to unlock other abilities. Wikipedia defines Gambit as a chess move opener, where one sacrifices a piece in order to gain an advantage. "The broader sense of "opening move meant to gain advantage" was first recorded in English in 1855." The gambit approach makes for an initially unusual style of play. It's been a while since I have played any games that rely on combos like that. You might think this sounds a little like playing a rogue in WoW, but I don't think so. Instead of building up combo points to unleash a finisher, different sequences of combo point builders result in different finishers. These builders are known as Gambit builders and come in three flavours: SP or quick thrust - places a spear in the gambit window SH or shield bash - places a shield in the gambit window FI or wardens taunt - places a fist in the gambit window As you level up different combinations of those builders unlock a specific Gambit. How many builders to do you need? It can be as little as 2, increasing to 5 at higher levels. As a result of the gambit builder approach, a warden's threat build up is slower, which is in contrast to a Guardian's which is instant. It relies on a mixture of damage over time (dots) and heal over time (hots) effects. There are also threat over time effects, but from reading they appear to be light threat effects and no where near as potent as the other over time effects, at later levels the HoTs in particular are the dominant AoE threat abilities, since they heal the whole group. The warden class only has one single target direct taunt ability - 5 gambit builders required http://lorebook.lotro.com/wiki/Warden:_Tanking_Guide Of note as well, Warden's don't wear heavy armor that is the domain of Guardians, and therefore rely on block and parry as well as their HoTs.

item.title: 4.01 is here
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded: It's been three days since the patch hit and rung in all the changes. Since I am still levelling, I can't comment on the DPS issues that warriors face since the patch came (the sky is always falling for some after a patch), but all I can say is I am really enjoying the changes. There were a few head scratching moments and a bit ofdisappointment to see certain abilities disappear or be moved to higher levels. I miss you Intercept,it was such a short lived affair before you were taken away from me :). Two more levels and we shall be re-united. Here's the build I settled on. I only have the prime and minor glyphs equipped as I findGlyph of Death Wish is just overpriced on Stormrage. 8o gold a pop and while I can understand that due to the changes glyphs are no longer disposable and a price rise was to be expected, I still think the price is a little steep. As an alternative I have been consideringGlyph of Victory Rush. Anyone who has ever levelled a warrior knows the pain of killing a few creatures, stop, sit down to eat, rinse and repeat all the way to the level cap. Now however, there's no more downtime! The change to Victory Rush combined with Bloodthirst, now easily allows us to storm into group after group of mobs and never really have to worry about your health or having to pause. Fury warriors are now truly a continuous killing machine, making levelling a breeze. I also tanked a few instances as Fury and was pleased to see that my rage generation was no longer a problem. Threat generation wasn't too bad either. Battle Shout (I did miss Bloodrage for about 2 minutes, but now that BS generates rage...), run in, Thunderclap, tab target Sunder Armor, then all you need to is Cleave and TC, whenever it's up and mobs should stick to you just fine, satisfying all of your groups AOE needs. Now that the patch has lowered the cost of Dual Talentspecialisationto 100 gold, I will soon take a peak at the tanking tree and giving it a whirl. My final comment is about the update to the textures, how gorgeous are they know? The water itself just makes me want to jump into it every time I see a puddle big enough!

item.title: Enchants
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded:
Just had a quick peak at the enchants published over at MMO Champion for Cataclysm and picked out the ones I thought might be interesting for tanks:
  • Boot - Mastery - Permanently enchant boots to increase mastery rating by 50.
  • Bracer - Dodge - Permanently enchant bracers to increase dodge rating by 50.
  • Bracer - Greater Expertise - Permanently enchant bracers to increase expertise rating by 50.
  • Chest - Greater Stamina - Permanently enchant a chest to increase Stamina by 75.
  • Chest - Mighty Stats - Permanently enchant chest armor to increase all stats by 15.
  • Chest -Peerless Stats - Permanently enchant chest armor to increase all stats by 20.
  • Chest -Stamina - Permanently enchant chest armor to increase Stamina by 55.
  • Cloak - Protection - Permanently enchant a cloak to increase armor by 250.
  • Gloves - Mastery - Permanently enchant gloves to increase mastery rating by 50.
  • Gloves - Mighty Strength - Permanently enchant gloves to increase Strength by 50.
  • Gloves - Exceptional Strength - Permanently enchant gloves to increase Strength by 35.
  • Gloves - Greater Expertise - Permanently enchant gloves to increase expertise rating by 50.
  • Shield - Blocking - Permanently enchant a shield to increase block rating by 40.
  • Shield - Protection - Permanently enchant a shield to increase armor by 160.
  • Ring - Greater Stamina - Permanently enchant your own ring to increase Stamina by 60. Enchanting your ring causes it to become soulbound and requires 475 Enchanting skill to remain active.

item.title: Stats focus @ 85
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded:
Not just stam (actually secondary stat)
Aim for 8 percent hit target and around 26 expertise, then strength. Threat is what new tanks should be focusing on.
Dodge, parry and the Critical Block mastery loom larger in such a scenario

item.title: Utgard Keep video
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded:
Just a testing video captured using fraps and merged using iMovie.

Clearly - Normal Utgard Keep from Greg Stewart on Vimeo.

One of the interesting things I noticed was that hello I am a clicker :) As a result of watching this video, I re-arranged my UI quite a bit and set up a number of key bindings. Still getting used to the new set up, I guess it'll take time for the muscle memory to set in.

item.title: Moments before Cataclysm launched
item.dc:creator: clearly

item.title: The road to 80
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded:
Tanking my way to 80 was painful, mainly because the dungeons were so easy and other characters completely outgeared the content. Between 1-60 folks were kitted out in Heirlooms and best possible enchants had more stam than my little tank did, that relied on drops. This resulted in cloth wearers with willy nilly blowing targets up and for the most part getting away with it. But every pull was chaotic, so very early on I specced into Fury and only really tanked when the signed up tank disconnected and we were waiting for a replacement. On the whole a fury warrior felt more effective in terms of threat generation, than a full prot build.
I remained Fury until 68, as between 60-70 things were still as chaotic and I don't particularly enjoy chasing after the cloth wearer that is running away from the tank.
At 68 or so I switched back to prot for levelling and while things didn't die as quickly, nor did I. The wrath dungeons worked out pretty well in terms of tanking, but then again, they felt incredibly familiar.

item.title: The path to 85 - part 1
item.dc:creator: clearly
item.content:encoded:
With much trepidation and a slight delay (no thanks to you Amazon) I started my path to 85. First up, Blizzard have done an amazing job with the new expansion. After grabbing Flight Master's license and doing a few laps of Oggrimar and beyond I pondered where to go to first Vashj'ir or Mount Hyjal? In the end I opted for the underwater world of Vashj'ir. The quest lines are really well designed and thought out. The Sea Legs ability is heaps of fun and actually reminds me of those movies you see of people walking on the moon. The water mount is also great little touche that just help with the immersion into this watery world. The 20,000 leagues under the sea themed quests often made me smile and progressing through the Naga themed quests was really awesome. I really enjoyed this zoon, though somehow I missed I seem to have skipped over some quests as I am ten or so shy of completing Sinking into Vashj'ir. Just running around this zone got me to 82, those two levels just seemed to fly by, 83 was more painful, 84 with it's 5 million xp requirement looked daunting, but nowhere near as intimidating as the 9.2 million required to get to 85!! The Throne of Tides instance was also a refreshing experience (always nice to learn new encounters), but I only got to run it once. While I could have moved onto Deepholm, Uldum or Twilight Highands, I opted for Mount Hyjal. Progress was a lot slower in terms of levelling, but the story line was once again well superbly constructed and I found more engaging than the Vashj'ir one, but maybe that was just because the characters were more familiar. Things certainly are more linear these days, and you don't seem to get lost quite as easily, though the number of people asking for advice still remains at ridiculous levels - shame they can't read the quest text eh?? You come across the second starter dungeon much sooner in Hyjal (and don't make the mistake I did in flying to Blackrock, just click on the little turret thing behind the quest giver). I really liked this dungeon and the encounters, so much so that I'll end this post for now with a little video of my run through it.

Blackrock caverns from Greg Stewart on Vimeo.

item.title: It's been quiet, oh so quiet
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
For wee while now I have been playing on my old stomping ground of US servers. I have levelled my hunter Safetyoff, druid Artaios and paladin Bubbleuc to 85. It's all been a bit random and as far as Artaios and BubbleUc have been concerned mainly as DPS, which gave me the best mix between doing quests and checking out the new dungeons. I have also been mucking round with a DK (Robertson - a lot of fun, but I have to admin I am clueless at this stage how both resources are managed) and my rogue Turpin.

I feel like getting back into tanking again and based on my current gear and rep levels below is a list of things I need to focus to change up.

[caption id="attachment_170" align="alignnone" width="691" caption="Random screenshot from the past"][/caption]

Artaios is revered with the Earthen Ring, so the head enchant is available and Bubbleuc has completed the quest chain for Therazane, but it's time to grind the rep and get to exalted by wearing the tabard and doing the dailies.

Below is a list of slots and what I need to change/enhance given my current gear. The order of the enhancements is:Enchants > Reforging > Gems. I am not going to worry to much about gear at this stage since most of it will just come over time with dungeons, rep and professions.

Bubble
Shield: Blocking > Dodge to Parry > nada
Weapon: Pyrium weapon chain > nada
Relic: nada > dodge to parry > Fractured Amberjewel

Head: Arcanum of the Earthen Ring > hit to mastery > nada
Neck: nada > haste to mastery > nada
Shoulders: Greater inscription of unbreakable quartz > hit to mastery > Fine ember Topaz
Cloak: Protection > dodge to parry > nada
Chest: Stamina > expertise to mastery > nada
Bracers: Dodge > expertise to mastery > nada
Hands: done > hit to mastery > nada
Belt: get belt socket > dodge to parry > Fractured Amberjewel
Legs: Twilight leg armor > hit to mastery > nada
Boots: done > hit to mastery > nada
Ring 1: get enchanter stam > hit to mastery > nada
Ring 2: get enchanter stam > nada > nada
Trinket 1: nada > dodge to mastery > nada
Trinket 2: nada > nada > nada

Artaios
Weapon: Done > haste to dodge > nada
Relic: nada > haste to dodge > Ideally Delicate Inferno Ruby

Head: Arcanum of the Earthen Ring > haste to dodge > wait for new items (Austere Shadowspirit Diamond + Shifting Demonseye)
Neck: nada > haste to dodge > nada
Shoulders: Greater inscription of unbreakable quartz > hit to dodge > wait for new items (Shifting Demonseye)
Cloak: Protection > haste to dodge > nada (>> switch in Cloak of Thredd)
Chest: done > hit to dodge > do nothing (Delicate Inferno Ruby + Shifting Demonseye)
Bracers: Draconic Embossment: Agility > Crit to Dodge > nada
Hands: Mastery rating > haste to dodge > Polished Ember Topaz
Belt: get belt socket > Expertise to dodge > (Delicate Inferno Ruby)
Legs: Charscale Leg Reinforcements > haste to dodge > do nothing (Polished Ember Topaz + Delicate Inferno Ruby)
Boots: Earthen vitality > hit to dodge > nada
Ring 1: get enchanter agility > hit to dodge > nada
Ring 2: get enchanter agility > haste to dodge > nada
Trinket 1: nada > mastery to dodge > nada
Trinket 2: nada > expertise to dodge > nada

Of note is that Paladins seem to focus on reforging to parry and mastery as the primary stats. Whereas Druids it's dodge all the way.

Oh and all of this was compiled thanks to Ask Mr Robot

item.title: Paladin tanking 4.06
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Some notes on Cataclysm Tanking/Protection Field Manual :: Updated Feb 9, 2011 (4.0.6)

General

    • Mastery "effectively" provides block rating (flat 30% damage reduction -> 40% with Holy Shield)
      Every point of Mastery provides 2.25% of block
      "blocks are no longer a fixed amount of mitigation but instead reduced damage by a certain percentage"
      you are aiming for 102.4% avoidance - aka the block cap
      Strength stat provides Parry rating
      8% requires 961 Hit rating

Reforging

    • Reforging: "If you are not at the block cap/full combat table coverage reforgein this orderhaste, crit, expertise, hit, dodge/parry into mastery"
      Once you hit 102.4% block - consider dodge/parry - but remember not too much or they push block of the hit table
      Never reforge into haste and crit

Glyphs (recommended ones)

    • Prime: [Glyph of Hammer of the Righteous]
      Prime: [Glyph of Seal of Truth]
      Prime: [Glyph of Shield of the Righteous]
      Major: [Glyph of Lay on Hands]

Encounters

Pull by using If single target use the following priority queue: / > > > (when active) > > > if AOE: Hammer of the Righteous > > > > / >

item.title: 4.1 is here
item.dc:creator: bubbleuc
item.content:encoded:
And here is my preliminary loot list:
  • Talonguard Band -Akil'zon <Eagle Avatar>
  • Spiritshield Mask -Nalorakk <Bear Avatar>
  • Pauldrons of Sacrifice -Hex Lord Malacrass
  • Legguards of the Unforgiving -Daakara <The Invincible>
  • (Coils of Hate -High Priest Venoxis) -> maybe not since I have crafted ones
  • Bloodlord's Protector -Bloodlord Mandokir
  • Bone Plate Handguards -Zanzil
  • Shield of the Blood God -Jin'do the Godbreaker

item.title: Blackwing Descent - Magmaw
item.dc:creator: bubbleuc
item.content:encoded:
A bit behind the times, but here's our first time kill video of Magmaw in BWD. Not the most exciting encounter, especially from a tanking perspective, very much tank and spank and certainly more of strain on the healers...

Magmaw from Greg Stewart on Vimeo.

item.title: Bastion of Twilight - Halfus Wyrmbreaker
item.dc:creator: bubbleuc
item.content:encoded:
After downing Magmaw and wiping for a bit on Omnitron Defense System we decided to head over to BOT. We'd done Halfus once previously on one of the harder combinations (which I didn't capture), but here's our most recent kill video. I did miss a couple of interrupts...

Halfus Wyrmbreaker from Greg Stewart on Vimeo.

This is certainly a more entertaining encounter, especially the first time round with the little drakes, Malevolent Strikes and fire combination. Little tip if you are tanking Halfus with the mortal strike abilitty as a Pally, useHand of Protection followed byHand of Freedom to reset the Malevolent Strikes debufs and buy yourself a bit of time before having to start your taunt rotation on Halfus.

item.title: Blackwing Descent - Maloriak
item.dc:creator: bubbleuc
item.content:encoded:
We finally got Maloriak down last night, yay for us. I found this encounter quite challenging, mainly because I was on add duty and rounding those buggers up can be a tad annoying. As you can see in the video, selecting them took me a while sometimes and luckily it was never after a Scorching Blast or the healers would have been toast. And there's a tip, they always go for the healers, so stand close to them when they spawn and it'll save you heaps of running round (this only really works if they don't pop during Scorching Blast - if they do, time for some running round).

Maloriak from Greg Stewart on Vimeo.

We had the help of team 1 alts (which always goes a long way so big thanks to them). Our initial tactic was to wait for 9 aberrations to be released before AOE-ing them down. While the first round never was a problem, come the second round, I'd invariably die as soon the next 9 were all on me. T1 suggested we go for 12/6 and boom we got him down. When you have 12 adds up it really helps if you have a mage in your group to cast Ring of Frost and if you have a DK, use Hungering Cold as well.

item.title: Atramedes down
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
After yet another short hiatus we managed to find our way back in Blackwing Descent. This time I remembered to capture the Omnotron Defense System encounter :) .

Omnotron Defense System from Greg Stewart on Vimeo.

After a few false starts on Maloriak, we were able to down him again as well and that opened up Atramades for us. Once again not an overly challenging encounter I thought, pretty much tank and spank with a little bit of running round during his air phase. A little tip if you are playing a Paladin, if he targets you with his Roaring Flame Breath, simply use your Hand of Protection and he will shift his attention to someone else during the air phase.

Atramedes from Greg Stewart on Vimeo.
